com.amazon.insights
Class AmazonInsights

java.lang.Object
  com.amazon.insights.AmazonInsights

public abstract class AmazonInsights
extends java.lang.Object

AmazonInsights is the entry point of the SDK.

For step by step instructions on how to integrate this SDK with your A/B tests, visit the Integrate the SDK page of the Amazon Insights A/B Testing documentation.

For step by step instructions on how to integrate this SDK with your Analytics Reports, visit the Integrate the SDK page of the Amazon Insights Analytics documentation.

To create an AmazonInsights instance for A/B Testing and/or Analytics, first create a new InsightsCredentials object by invoking the newCredentials(String, String) method. When creating your credentials, use the Public and Private keys of the Identifier you setup in the Amazon Developer Portal. See the Amazon Insights Documentation for more information on how to create and use Identifiers.

You create an AmazonInsights instance by calling newInstance(InsightsCredentials, Context) with your credentials and the Android ApplicationContext.

Example:

 // Using the Identifier you created in the Amazon Developer Portal site, create a credentials object with the Identifier's Public and Private Keys
 // The Identifier's Public Key acts as the application key.
 InsightsCredentials credentials = AmazonInsights.newCredentials(YOUR_APP_KEY, YOUR_PRIVATE_KEY);
 
 // initialize a new instance of AmazonInsights
 // The AmazonInsights library requires the Android context in order to access
 // Android services (i.e. SharedPrefs, etc)
 AmazonInsights insightsInstance = AmazonInsights.newInstance(credentials, getApplicationContext());

You can also customize an AmazonInsights instance by calling the newInstance(InsightsCredentials, Context, InsightsOptions) method with an InsightsOptions object. Initializing the SDK this way allows you to enable/disable event collection and enable/disable WAN delivery of events.

Example:

 // Using the Identifier you created in the Amazon Developer Portal site, create a credentials object with the Identifier's Public and Private Keys
 // The Identifier's Public Key acts as the application key.
 InsightsCredentials credentials = AmazonInsights.newCredentials(YOUR_APP_KEY, YOUR_PRIVATE_KEY);
 
 // create an options object with event collection enabled and WAN delivery enabled 
 InsightsOptions options = AmazonInsights.newOptions(true, true);
 
 // initialize a new instance of AmazonInsights
 // The AmazonInsights library requires the Android context in order
 // to access Android services (i.e. SharedPrefs, etc)
 AmazonInsights insightsInstance = AmazonInsights.newInstance(credentials, getApplicationContext(), options);

After you create an AmazonInsights instance, you can either maintain the reference to the AmazonInsights instance yourself or access it later by using the getInstance(InsightsCredentials).

Example:

 // After creating the instance, you can either hold onto this instance
 // or use the static accessor by providing a credentials object that
 // uses the same App key and Private key used for initialization.
 InsightsCredentials credentials = AmazonInsights.newCredentials(YOUR_APP_KEY, YOUR_PRIVATE_KEY);
 AmazonInsights originalInstance = AmazonInsights.getInstance(credentials);

Once you create an instance, you can:

  • access the ABTestClient to retrieve variations
  • access the EventClient to create, record, and submit events
  • access the SessionClient to manage sessions
  • access the Monetization Builders to record monetization purchase events.
  • access the UserProfile to update dimensions used for Segmentation

Constructor Detail

AmazonInsights

protected AmazonInsights()
Method Detail

newCredentials

public static InsightsCredentials newCredentials(java.lang.String applicationKey,
                                                 java.lang.String privateKey)
Create a new InsightsCredentials instance

Parameters:
applicationKey - The Public key of the Identifier you created in the Amazon Developer Portal. Currently the Public Key of an Amazon Insights Identifier also acts as the Application key.
privateKey - The Private key of the Identifier you created in the Amazon Developer Portal
Returns:
a new InsightsCredentials instance with the specified public and private key

newDefaultOptions

public static InsightsOptions newDefaultOptions()
Create an InsightsOptions object set to the Insights SDK defaults.

Returns:
An InsightsOptions object where: InsightsOptions.getAllowEventCollection() is true InsightsOptions.getAllowWANDelivery() is false

newOptions

public static InsightsOptions newOptions(boolean allowEventCollection,
                                         boolean allowWANDelivery)
Create a new InsightsOptions object with the specified values

Parameters:
allowEventCollection - enable/disable event collection for the entire SDK
allowWANDelivery -
  • true - allows events to be submitted when the user has either a WAN or WIFI connection to the internet
  • false - events are only submitted when the user has a WIFI connection to the internet
Returns:
a new InsightsOptions object with the specified values

getInstance

public static AmazonInsights getInstance(InsightsCredentials credentials)
                                  throws java.lang.IllegalArgumentException
Return the AmazonInsights instance that was created with the specified credentials

Parameters:
credentials - The credentials used to initially create the instance
Returns:
The AmazonInsights instance with the specified credentials
Throws:
java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - An AmazonInsights instance with the specified credentials was not found

                                         android.content.Context appContext)

Parameters:
credentials - The credentials created from the Amazon Insights Identifier
appContext - The Android ApplicationContext
Returns:
an AmazonInsights instance
Throws:
